resources.string: \t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tSelect a Picture Story to load.\nSeleccione una historia de imagen para cargar.
Maria was sick last year.\nMaria estuvo enferma el año pasado.
She did not go to the doctor.\nElla no fue al médico.
One night she could not breathe.\nUna noche no pudo respirar.
Her husband took her to the emergency room.\nSu esposo la llevó a la sala de emergencias.
She stayed in the hospital for three days.\nElla permaneció en el hospital por tres días.\n(PART ONE END)
Maria is sick again. She has a bad cough.\nMaria está enferma de nuevo. Ella tiene una tos fuerte.
She does not want the cough to get worse. She does not want to go to the emergency room.\nElla no quiere que la tos empeore. Ella no quiere ir a la sala de emergencias.
She calls the health center to make an appointment.\nElla llama al centro de salud para hacer una cita.
She also asks for an interpreter.\nElla también pide un intérprete.\n(PART TWO END)
At the health center they ask Maria, "What is your name?"\nEn el centro de salud le preguntan a Maria: "¿Cómo te llamas?"
They ask, "Do you have health insurance?"\nPreguntan: "¿Tiene seguro de salud?"
Maria gives them her insurance card.\nMaria les da su tarjeta de seguro.\n(PART 3 END)
They give her a form to fill out. The form is in English. Maria asks for a form in Spanish.\nLe dan un formulario para completar. El formulario está en inglés. Maria pide un formulario en español.
Maria asks for an interpreter.\nMaria pide un intérprete.\n(STORY END)
1. Why did Maria go to the hospital? ¿Por qué fue Maria al hospital?
2. Why does she make an appointment at the health center?\n¿Por qué hace una cita en el centro de salud?
3. What do they ask Maria when she arrives at the health center?\n¿Qué le preguntan a María cuando llega al centro de salud?
4. Why does she ask for an interpreter? ¿Por qué pide una intérprete?
John is 50 years old.\nJohn tiene 50 años.
He is a healthy man.\nEl es un hombre sano.
Once a year he goes to his primary care physician for a checkup.\nUna vez al año acude a su médico de atención primaria para un chequeo.\n(PART 1 END)
He calls his primary care center to make an appointment.\nLlama a su centro de atención primaria para hacer una cita.
He says, "I need to make an appointment for a checkup."\nÉl dice: "Necesito hacer una cita para un chequeo".
The woman on the phone says, "Please come in on Tuesday at 4:30 pm."\nLa mujer en el teléfono dice: "Por favor, vengan el martes a las 4:30 pm".\n(PART 2 END)

When John arrives at the primary care center, the woman at the front desk gives him a health history form.\nCuando John llega al centro de atención primaria, la mujer de la recepción le entrega un formulario de historial de salud.
He fills out the health history form while he waits for the physician\'s assistant.\nRellena el formulario de historial de salud mientras espera al asistente del médico.\n(PART 3 END)
The form asks, "Do you have any allergies? Do you take any medicines?"\nEl formulario pregunta: "¿Tiene alguna alergia? ¿Toma algún medicamento?"
He thinks of the questions to ask the physician\'s assistant.\nPiensa en las preguntas para hacerle al asistente del médico.\n(STORY END)
1. How does John stay healthy?\n¿Cómo se mantiene saludable John?
2. Why does he call his primary care physician?\n¿Por qué llama a su médico de atención primaria?
3. What do they give John when he arrives at the primary care center?\n¿Qué le dan a John cuando llega al centro de atención primaria?
4. What questions do you think John will ask his primary care physician?\n¿Qué preguntas cree que John le hará a su médico de atención primaria?
Alicia went to the doctor.\nAlicia fue al médico.
The doctor gave her a prescription.\nEl doctor le dio una receta.
Alicia took the prescription to the pharmacy.\nAlicia llevó la receta a la farmacia.
She gave the prescription to the pharmacist.\nElla le dio la receta al farmacéutico.
The pharmacist filled the prescription and gave her the medicine.\nEl farmacéutico llenó la receta y le dio el medicamento.
Alicia asked the pharmacist, "How do I take this medicine?"\nAlicia le preguntó al farmacéutico: "¿Cómo tomo este medicamento?"
The pharmacist said, "Take two, twice a day."\nEl farmacéutico dijo: "Tome dos, dos veces al día".
1. What is the name of the medicine?\n¿Cuál es el nombre de la medicina?
2. How much medicine will Alicia take each day?\n¿Cuánta medicina tomará Alicia cada día?
3. How often will she take it each day?\n¿Con qué frecuencia lo tomará cada día?
4. How many pills are in the bottle?\n¿Cuántas pastillas hay en la botella?
5. What does the warning label say?\n¿Qué dice la etiqueta de advertencia?

Larisa\'s family eats too much meat and not enough fruits and vegetables. Larisa wants to make her family a healthy meal.\nLa familia de Larisa come demasiada carne y no tienes suficientes frutas y verduras. Larisa quiere hacer de su familia una comida saludable.

Help Larisa make a healthy meal for her family. Choose food from the five food groups.\nAyuda a Larisa a preparar una comida saludable para su familia. Elija alimentos de los cinco grupos de alimentos.
Make Another Meal\n/ Hacer Otra Comida
Would you like to make another?\n¿Te gustaría hacer otro?
Select a Take Parts activity to load.\nSeleccione una actividad Tomar partes para cargar.
Drag the correct word on to the correct spot.
Read Story Again \n/ Lea la historia \notra vez
Congratulations! You have completed the exercise!
Reading: Where Do I Go For Health Care?
When you are well, see your doctor for a checkup. Your doctor will look for problems you do not see or feel. Finding a health problem early may save your life.
When you are sick, go to your primary care center. Your primary care center is the place to go for all your basic health care needs. Call your primary care center to make an appointment.
When you have an emergency, go to the hospital emergency room or call 911. An Emergency is when you have a serious medical problem that needs to be addressed right away.
Hello, health center, how may I help you?
Hello, this is Fatima Tuma. I want to make an appointment.
How do you spell your name?
I have a headache and sore throat.
Reading: What will the doctor ask me?
What are your symptoms? Before you go to the doctor, practice describing your symptoms in English. Practice with a friend or a family member.

What medicine do you take? Before you go to the doctor, write down the names of medicines you take and how much you take each day. Give this list to your doctor. Or you can bring your medicines with you and show them to the doctor.
What is your health history? Your health history is the health problems you have now or had in the past. Your doctor will always ask you to fill out a health history form.
Reading: What will I ask the doctor?
Be sure you understand the answers to these questions before you leave your appointment.
What do I need to do/how do I take my medication?
Why is it important for me to do this?
What if I am getting worse?
How do I get my medicine? Where do I go?
What are the side effects of my medicine?
It is your doctors job to clearly explain the answers to these questions.
It is your job to be sure you understand the answers before you leave the doctors office.
Hello, my name is Dr.Watson. How may I help you?
I have pain in my back.
Yes, it hurts when I walk
What is causing my back pain?
I can give you some medicine to help. Take it two times a day.
How long should I take the medicine?
Take all the medicine. It should last about one week.
Hello, how can I help you?
I need to find over the counter medication for allergies.
I have a headache and I sneeze often.
Here is a medicine that works for many people. Try this medicine.
Will this medicine cause side effects?
This label says the medicine may make you feel sleepy.
Is there a medicine that will not make me sleepy?
Healthy eating means the body is getting the food it needs to stay healthy. Healthy eating can prevent obesity and other health problems.

Other health problems that can be avoided or lessened by healthy eating: Diabetes, High Cholesterol, Osteoporosis, Cancer, Heart Disease and Stroke, High Blood Pressure, Depression, and Eating Disorders.
Reading: More Variety in Your Diet
To stay healthy you need to eat foods from the 5 food groups. These 5 food groups are Fruits, Dairy, Protein, Vegetables, and Grains.
Reading: Eat More Fruits and Vegetables
One of the best things you can do for your health is eat more fruits and vegetables. Fruits and vegetables give you the fiber and vitamins your body needs to stay healthy.
People should work to eat 2 servings of fruit and 5 servings of vegetables each day.

Examples of a serving are: 1 small apple, 1 large orange, 1 cup of leafy greens(lettuce, spinach, kale), 1 small bell pepper, 1/2 a cup of berries(blueberries, strawberries, grapes), 2 medium carrots.
What fruits do you like to eat?
I like to eat oranges and apples.
What vegetables do you like to eat?
I like to eat broccoli and carrots.
Do you like to eat spinach?
No, I do not like to eat spinach. Do you?
No, I do not like spinach either.
Do you like to eat strawberries?
Yes, strawberries are my favorite food
